reviewText: The movie is real, real people, real decisions. Many may not like it and its not going to end the way most movies end but the world is not all butterflies flying to the sky, sometimes people just fall and this movie shows us what happens when things go spiraling out of control.

This is a great film for quite a few reasons. Since the other reviewers mention a lot of them. Ill say ditto to the 4 and 5 reviewers and add my bit.
For me this film was about separation from the plan an individual makes when they are young, and finding out that that path is not necessarily the one which is right for you.
Marc seemed to come from a family of policemen and had been groomed by that family to follow in their footsteps. Anyone who has support from their parents will understand this. Parents love by trying to make sure their child doesnt make the mistakes they made or they saw others make. They mean well, but often don't see who their child truly is. The child is a child so blindly follows the chosen path, until they wake up.
Sometimes they wake by themselves, sometime an incident wakes them. In this case Kay woke Marc.
Basically if/when you wake up, it can be painful, as you realize you are truly alone in the world. However once you make peace with that, it is ever so liberating and you are free to be who and what you chose.
 I believe this is why we are always told not to be in such a rush to grow up. It takes time to learn how to observe before you act. This is why many of us end up with houses, spouses and children without ever understanding that these things are not what we are looking for. Or if we do want these things, we do not take into account how much of our Selves we have to give to each of these things.
As far as the gay angle, well we humans love to persecute any thing, idea or one that is different, which to me translates as if you are persecuting someone you are either jealous or afraid... Yeah,  you are a Pussy. Instead of lashing out, go inside and figure out what the hell scares you so much and face it. Yes, gay person here. Great film on many levels.

Released in Germany as `Freir Fall' this has been compared to `Brokeback Mountain', but apart from it being about a man who is gay in a heterosexual relationship, I can't really see any other similarities. We meet Marc who is a cop and he has a pregnant girlfriend and what appears to be a life plan. Then at the academy he meets Kay who is more free whelin' than him and after getting off on the wrong foot they slowly hit it off.

Now despite the police or polizei being all inclusive these days there is still a vast undercurrent of homophobia and this is shown and there is some violence. Soon Marc realises what he wants and moreover who he wants but societal pressures and the arrival of his new baby son are all contributing to making him want to hurt the one he really loves.

This is a rather good film the two male leads are always guaranteed to put in a solid performance.  Marc is played by Hanno Kofler - `Krabat' and the excellent `Summer Storm'. Kay is played by Max Riemelt - `Napola' and `The Fourth State'. The sub titles are good to ok as they are not always a literal translation which I know some prefer but I like it told straight. This is a film that will not tick all the boxes, the ending especially may fail to deliver for some viewers; there is a limited amount of scenes of a sexual nature but nothing to frighten the horses of even a randy pony to be honest. However, this is still a very strong film with some excellent performances indeed - recommended to fans of gay themed cinema.

A very interesting and complex film. There is a prominent adage in psychology circles that what attracts people to either the military or police work as professions ,is an internal lack of order, and the need for rules from an external source. The adage seems to apply here. Mark, especially is a person who is looking for answers as to how to behave in society. He attempts to follow every rule presented to him, and mete them out, but gets completely thrown off by his attraction to his police classmate, Kay.
I'm not at all convinced that Mark is gay. He is so self-centered that he seems to lack the capacity to engage emotionally with anyone ,and there is not much hope he will, even after deciding to leave the structure of his girlfriend and baby, and relationship with Kay. He'd best stay in the police department where the structure is clear, rigid and codified.
Kay, on the other hand really has a chance to succeed in life. He may break away from the police department, is much more grounded about his sexual orientation and emotionally mature.
The acting in the film and pacing is uniformly great. All the actors do a great job in their roles and it's interesting to see a slice of modern German society in action.
An long known fact is that in societies where there are rigid cultural and gender rules, the incidents of homosexuality is much greater than in societies where the gender roles are much more relaxed. Germany has always been an overtly homophobic society and has had an underground of gay sub culture. It would be worthwhile to see how many gay folks there are in the German police department, nationwide.
 The other thing I enjoyed about the film is that not a scene in the movie was wasted. Even the small scenes seemed to be going somewhere and where there for a reason. Well worth buying the film to watch again at another time.

I heard this described as a German "Brokeback Mountain" - a concept difficult to grasp given that it takes place in the present and that Germany, generally speaking, is a good deal less homophobic than the US.  Anyway, this film tells the story of two police cadets who rather suddenly, inexplicably fall hard for each other.  The one cadet, Kay, is close to being openly gay and has few qualms telling Marc, the other cadet, that he wants him.  Marc resists and then caves time and again until he finds himself in love.  With a kid on the way and parents living next door, you can feel him being smothered.  The other officers have accepted Marc into the fold but only as a straight man.  (They marginalize and discriminate against Kay.)  And the only way Marc seems to get any credit from anyone in his life is by engaging in "traditional" male behavior - except for Kay who genuinely cares for Marc and is quite unhappy without him.  How Marc reconciles all of this is the conflict at the center but what a conflict it is!  It does involve some of the themes in "Brokeback Mountain" - feeling stuck between two worlds, discomfort in one's skin, brazen homophobia - but it ends there.  It concludes on a ??? note which is all I can really say.  The writing is strong and compelling and the acting is spot-on.  The direction is wise - it is accurate, meaning that it spends just the right amount of time with each couple.  It also uses images to highlight aggression and homophobic violence.  It doesn't preach.  It assumes the audience will have the right reaction.  Of course, there is the issue of "sex scenes", an issue I only address because people obsess over it.  The gay scenes are something I would like to see more of - realistic, assumptive, emphasis on kissing and caressing, simply classy.  Queer men and most straight women would probably approve and secure straight men would probably just shrug (and that makes for well over 60% of the viewing audience - just a note to Hollywood).  I rather liked this film - it catches the imagination and presents a very real dilemma that really does take place.

Some aspects of this movie struck me as a sexual/political fantasy by the filmmaker.  Also, while we are given a fairly straightforward story line, there's little character development to help us understand how the married protagonist, Marc,  is so easily drawn into a gay relationship from which he is obviously helpless to extricate himself.  Prior to being "seduced" (if that's the right word) there is nothing that would suggest he is anything but a straight, married and expectant father.  This also makes it difficult to empathize with him, since he is continually lying to his wife.  He comes off as being more irresponsible than anything else, since we don't see what inner, inexorable psychological driver prevents him from resisting his impulses.  He does say, when the truth finally comes out, that he "doesn't understand" how it happened - but then, really,  neither do we.  There's also a predatory aspect to Kay, the gay seducer, which I found pretty unappealing.  Like a stalker, he is unrelenting and seems to care little about the consequences.  A character like that simply gives ammunition to those who see gay men as having predatory natures.  I would say that the anguish Marc feels when his relationship with his wife is falling apart was performed very well, and was moving.

Calling Freier Fall/Free Fall the "German 'Brokeback Mountain'" is tempting because of the similarities (and almost as bleak an ending, though not quite). However, it's not an entirely accurate comparison for a few reasons.

First, Brokeback Mountain followed the two lead male characters and the development of their relationship with each other, as well as their separate lives away from each other -- over multiple decades and locations. Second, Brokeback Mountain was very much about both Jack and Ennis and their love.

Free Fall's two male characters are not both equally developed or followed. Marc, the previously hetero cop, is the primary focus. The changes in his life are portrayed (as well as the consequences and fallout).

Also, in Brokeback Mountain, both men were presented originally as heterosexuals, who went on to maintain 'normal' heterosexual relationships with women more or less successfully in terms of what was expected of them (marrying, having kids, raising families).

By contrast, Free Fall primarily follows what happens to Marc while he moves in to a new house next door to his parents with his pregnant girlfriend and slowly, simultaneously gets involved with a gay fellow cop. While his girlfriend and his lover are also portrayed, Marc is the primary character.

Kay, the cop Marc falls in love with, identifies as gay, though he is not openly gay at the police academy where they meet. The relationship between Marc and Kay is not portrayed over the long span of time that Jack and Ennis' relationship occurred in Brokeback Mountain. It is followed over a much shorter time span.

One similarity between the two films is the homophobic environments in which these male/male relationships arise. As enlightened as modern Germany may be, police forces tend to be less so, rather like the military, especially for open homosexuals or lesbians.

Though not delved into as deeply as it was in Brokeback, we also see the consequences for one of the women involved with one of these men.

A question raised by both films--indirectly in Brokeback, but openly in Free Fall--is: is this man gay?

By having and continuing to have heterosexual relations, by being gay only with one other specific man, what are they?

**SPOILERS**
In Free Fall, while Kay identifies as gay and encourages Marc to do so, too, Marc refuses. He says he's not gay. Is that internalized homophobia, or is it his truth? During an argument, Marc's girlfriend Bettina asks him if he's gay, and he denies it. She demands to know, "What are you then!?" and he replies, "I don't know."

Marc, lonely (and probably looking for Kay after Kay has moved out and left no forwarding address), goes alone to the gay club where he and Kay used to go. He almost gets a blow job from a stranger in the bathroom -- but stops at the last moment, almost punching the guy out.

Is he homophobic?

Is he just angry because it's not Kay, the man he loves and wants and is probably looking for?

Or is it because he's not gay?

One senses, by the end of the film, that Marc returns to the academy and training because it is all he has left.

**END SPOILERS**

By the end of the film, we see that once you cease to be unambiguously heterosexual, you are perceived as "gay" whether you identify as gay, or not... with all the personal and professional costs attached to that perception.

By limiting its focus to one main character and restricting the time frame to a relatively short one, Free Fall lacks the sweeping, epic feel of Brokeback Mountain. Nevertheless, it is a well acted, well directed film that elicits sympathy for Marc, who unexpectedly finds himself on the outside of all he has known, just by loving someone he wasn't supposed to.

Also, the two male leads are pretty gorgeous and the sex scenes are pretty hot, so there's an eye candy appeal here. There aren't that many of them, and they aren't that explicit, though they are more explicit than Brokeback Mountain and (if I recall correctly) there are more of them.

If you liked the Jack/Ennis sex and romance scenes of Brokeback Mountain (or were one of the many women who didn't *know* you liked that sort of thing, until you saw it in Brokeback Mountain and were like, whoa, hot!), you'll like it in Free Fall.

Freier Fall, in which two ostensibly straight males fall into bouts of illicit lovemaking in inhospitable locations, plays like an adolescent homosex phantasy. It's accordingly derivative and predictable, like most films that put homosexual arousal center stage, then figure out a scenario that will make the inevitable lip-locking as implausible as possible for the biggest pay-off. With rare exceptions (Marco Berger's Plan B comes to mind) this inevitable meeting of mucus membranes eventuates with the suddenness of an act of desperate violence. To that end Stephen Lacant spends an inordinate amount of time establishing the masculine bone fides of the protagonists, to such an extent that it threatens to become the main focus of the film. Given the plasticity of the male sexual response in homosocial environments, the scenario of two police cadets getting the hots for one another is not incredible--but neither is it novel or particularly interesting. Lacant has merely produced his version of the standard doomed gay romance. Films dealing with homosexual persecution and paranoia have been made since the 1970s (Wolfgang Peterson's Die Konsequenz and Claude Miller's The Best Way to Walk come to mind)--with greater nuance and humanity. The experience of inconvenient homoerotic arousal in and of itself is an insufficient thematic for average filmmakers, I don't care how much splicing and edgy verit stylization its packaged in. Protagonists whose sole purpose is to channel anomalous sexual predilections wind up as ciphers of animal mediocrity.

Freier Fall's similarity to Brokeback Mountain has been remarked upon. I would draw parallels with another recent film about illicit homosexual bonding, Nicolo Donato's disturbing Broderskab (Brotherhood 2009). Again, the comparison is to the detriment of the formulaic Freier Fall. Donato's film was vastly superior because the homosexual attraction wasn't front & center, but one factor in a complex of engaging, if rather horrifying, themes.

Max Riemelt, who plays Kay is a telegenic and engaging presence on screen, if not quite in the league of Volker Bruch in terms of intensity. Hanno Koffler as the repressed (or just clueless?) Marc broods with the best of them, but has the physicality of a Guinea Pig on steroids. A walking muscle-mass with tunnel vision, hair-trigger fuse, and a lecherous-malign glint in his eyes, he resembles a figure out of a Lucas Cranach portrait. Yet for all his irascibility, borderline autism, and  inarticulacy, he's not particularly spirited.

With cortisol surges and the fight-flight reflex dictating events, flying fists and sudden retreat are the inevitable outcome of every encounter that doesn't end in furtive homosex. I get that these two are struggling with illicit desires in a no-win situation, but their inability to converse with one another as persons radically limits their appeal. That well-spokenness kills the mood of rude and randy man-on-manism seems to be a generally accepted fact among primitivists and pornographers, but give me a break. These two academy trainees spend all their time either working out, fighting, or having sex. (You know, like real men...) Oh, and Marc has a pregnant girlfriend who turns into an real nag when his interest wanes, sealing the deal of his straight-arrow credentials.

Romance risks comedy when it confronts lovers with the necessity of its normalization. Once domesticated passionate partnerships generally transform into delicate, maintenance intensive stand-offs. Kay and Marc, inhabiting the realm of non-negotiable erotic impulses, never get that far. Their relationship, while tested by divided loyalties, lacks the civilizing dimension of habit and the intimacy of two minds meeting in sympathy. It remains a conflict (fight) resolved by the (SPOILERS!) sudden absconding (flight) of one of the partners.

There's not enough within this story to justify the happenings. *Maybe Spoilers* Handsome married Marc is at police academy and befriends hot, rule-bending Kay. We see Marc open to Kay's rule bending influence, but overwhelmingly we see him engaged in a happy married life with a lovely pregnant wife and supportive family. Almost randomly Kay forces himself on Marc. After some exposition of Marc's inner struggle, a sexual affair ensues. We see it coming, cause it's on the cover art for the film; but there's not enough in the story to see it coming. Later, although Kay doesn't seem the type, he professes love for Marc. After Marc's mother catches them kissing, Kay confesses his feelings to Marc's parents, when they confront him at a party at Marc's house, sooooo that's not right. The story isn't Fatal Attraction like so what gives? Obviously Marc has feelings of attachment to Kay but never confesses love for him. He denies being gay after the affair is discovered and the film even shows Marc unable to engage in sex with another guy during an emotional bottoming out. (I hate gay sex used as rock-bottom for an emotionally distressed person; as in "Shame.") So therein lies the problem with the storytelling; What is the story telling? The unsatisfying end doesn't give closure. It gives an impression that Marc will be OK. But the good people around him and their stories are left shattered. That's not like Marc; he's no sociopath; so again, what gives? We might conclude he was suffocating in a really great life and the affair was his escape, but there was something specific for him about Kay, and nothing to indicate the emotional burden. Maybe it's a cautionary tale for "hot for married guy" gays; Look what your lust shall bestow! Nah, it's a story of self discovery; of the power, surprise and consequence of unexpected physical attraction, though it doesn't say so. Uptick to 3 stars for production, acting talent and many elements of the story that left me feeling a lot. Down-tick to 3 stars for a vague narrative that renders a plausible plot confounding and well played characters incomplete.

I just received this film today and finished watching it already.  Free Fall ("Freier Fall" auf Deutsch) is a MUST HAVE, MUST BUY! Both main stars, Max Riemelt and Hanno Koffler, are superb as two policemen who become star-crossed lovers.  Koffler's character, Marc  is living with his girlfriend and they are expecting a baby anytime soon, so the complications are immediate.  Katharina Schüttler plays Marc's girlfriend very well, with the joy of romance and imminent motherhood, and the tragedy of discovering your partner has been in an affair, all portrayed with great skill.  Supporting cast are also all quite good, and editing is seamless.  The English version has the German language with English subtitles, but the movie is so good, you'll probably forget you're reading the subtitles very quickly.  It's good to hear these actors' voices anyway.
One side note:  The DVD has the two leading actor's names in the summary notes on the back cover confused with the other's role.  Also, Riemelt's name is misspelled as "Reimelt" in the leading paragraph of the Wolfe should correct this!  I'm going to check the Blu-Ray and German version to see if they are also incorrect, since I am interested in buying a Blu-Ray version.

Bottled up feelings can come out in words or actions.  Marc doesn't talk much.  His father had to drag words out of him as a child.  In a family of policemen, the hurt and angry Marc didn't learn to express his feelings.  He acts them out, much like an adolescent would.  The problem is that he's about to become a father, lives with his pregnant girlfriend next door to his parents, and is falling in love with his Shadow, the handsome Kay, who knows he's gay.  Unable to process his feelings with words, Marc acts out and betrays everyone, including himself.  This is a brilliantly acted film.  That it is in German doesn't really matter, most of the message is visual in the body language.  Any man who has gone through the transition of fatherhood will be able to relate to the repressed feelings needing to get out.  How we deal with our feelings creates the consequences.  In a world of double values in transition this film says it all.

Did we really need another movie about how stupid straight men are, about how brutal homophobia is, or about how cowardly married men who lust after other men are? Haven't we gotten past this crap - like about 20 years ago? Maybe they haven't in Germany. Maybe this movie (which is being touted as "the German Brokeback Mountain" by its US distributor) has a useful function for Germans, if they're really as thick-headed and slow as this movie makes them seem. But we gay men in the West, who've been fed the same old same old same old depressing homophobic crap year after year after year, have had enough already. Like Brokeback (which I also hated) this is a movie BY straight people (on both sides of the camera) and FOR straight people, who really may be so dumb that they need to see it all over again. WE! DON'T! I hated this ugly, depressing movie. Even Max Riemelt (Kay), one of the most beautiful men in the world, looks bad here - and what he would ever see in Hanno Koffler (Marc), one of the ugliest, is beyond imagining. There is no "chemistry" between them, by the way, only dark, slogging depression, dishonesty and cowardice - in Marc, who, unfortunately, is the star of this movie, and the only character who is given even the shallowest bit of depth. If you're German, or a homophobe, or a straight married man who'd rather be gay but doesn't have the GUTS it takes to be gay - then this movie may be for you. If you're a gay man who loves being gay, watch Pit Stop instead. It's fantastic, the best gay movie ever (unless you're an action addict).

I agree the acting is superb and the characters are real and compelling.  I was drawn into Marc and Kay's love affair.  And the shock of it all to his wife and family rang true.  But I didn't see Marc transitioning from straight to gay.  There is a real chemistry between he and is wife.  And at the beginning,  there is no sign that Marc has any doubt about his relationship with Bettina.  He most probably has had same gender attraction.  But, as is often the case, the attraction was mild enough that he has never been moved to act on it.  It is clear he is surprised and confused by the strength of his attraction to Kay. And as the relationship develops, his growing love for Kay creates a no win situation for his most important relationships.  Just as with Brokeback Mountain,  Free Fall exposes the reality of male sexuality.  It is not binary.....straight or gay.  While some men will be attracted only to women and so the term straight truly applies to them.  And other men are attracted only to other men...so identifying as gay is accurate.  But there are untold numbers of men who will have varying degrees of same gender attraction that can also vary through out their life time.  Marc is clearly not gay.  He has an ongoing sexual relationship with his wife.  He father's a child.  But when the right guy, Kay, comes along with the right chemistry....Marc experiences a very real and very strong same gender attraction, which leads to same gender sex.  And ultimately, love.

Together,  Free Fall and Brokeback Mountain give the best portrayal of male sexuality.  Kay depicts a solid Kinsey 6.  Jack Twist in Brokeback is the 3/4 Kinsey and clearly bisexual.  Marc's character is not fully formed sexually...but he is also bisexual.  Just not clear on which side of 3 he may land.  And Ennis Delmar is a perfect Kinsey 1.  Jack Twist was a one time deal for him.  These two films offer most men the best opportunity they will ever have to learn and understand the diversity male sexuality.

This is a movie I absolutely enjoyed on many levels. The movie gives insights into conditioned upbringing, a clear demarcation of whats considered to be right and whats wrong but at what price? Everything in his life looks okay until Kay walks in and introduces him to what can best described as a whiff of fresh air. With freedom comes responsibility and for someone like Marc this is extremely difficult. He has been taught and groomed to make everyone happy at the price of his own. So when he experiences adventure, freedom, a sense of flight and happiness with Kay, he is unable to accept it or adjust to it. Interwoven within the movie premise are societal attitudes towards homosexuality. Marc's life goes into a state of free fall when he develops feelings for his male police partner, Kay. Torn between the life he knows so well and the exhilaration of this new adventure, Marc finds his world rapidly spinning out of control. "Free Fall" is a moving portrayal of what happens when life plans crumble and there is no way left to fulfill the needs of the people you love.

A pity that so many will see this as merely some sort of sexual statement. The subtle interplay of personal dynamics among all the characters portrayed is outstanding. What I saw played out was a small tragedy, the loss of fulfilling relationships triggered by the emotional self-deception of the protagonist. The uncomfortable conclusion is that one can't have one's cake and eat it too. A shame as well that the under-stated dialogue between the lovers in simply not transferable from German to English. Not for everyone - I for one found it a rewarding reminder of my years in Germany.
